etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Charles Shepard (1804–1886). From French adinole from ancient Greek ἁδινός crowded, abundant (from the same base as ἄδην enough + -νος, suffix forming nouns) + an element of uncertain origin (perhaps French -ole, although the semantic motivation is unclear)

definitions: A hard, fine-grained rock, rich in albite, resulting from contact metamorphism of shales, slates, etc.

notes.text: Originally described by Beudant as a mineral species, a form of albite.
